data.title: snippet stop working after extension:Python installed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T16:21:53.542Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393, windows 10 Pro 1607 x64
- Extensions: donjayamanne.python-0.4.2, magicstack.MagicPython-0.5.17, ms-vscode.PowerShell-0.7.2, tht13.python-0.2.3, tushortz.python-extended-snippets-0.0.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install VS code on D: drive which is not OS drive
2. snippet works before I install the extension: python-0.4.2
3. my python path is D:/Program Files (x86)/python3.5/python.exe, and I configured setting item:
"python.pythonPath": "\"D:/Program Files (x86)/python3.5/python.exe\""
4. Snippet stops to work after I install the extension: python-0.4.2 : the snippet doesn't pop up anymore.

Expectation:
Snippet should works after I install the extension: python-0.4.2.

More info:
I installed the extension/VSCode on a server which OS is windows 2008 R2 and python path is 'C:/Python34/python.exe', snippet works well.

I have opened an [issue](https://github.com/DonJayamanne/pythonVSCode/issues/397#issuecomment-254736290) for Python extension, the author doubt that this is a VSCode issue, I would like to provide more info to locate the root cause.

Thanks,

data.title: Question: is it possible to test userinteraction?
data.body:
When an extension developer is writing some tests (hopefully).
Is there any possibility to test for user interaction?

E.g.

The code shows an input box where the user has to input a filename for example. Now my unit test would insert "foobar" there and hit enter. The main reason would be to test some features and functions that depend on a users input.

I've not found any documentation on this matter.

Cheers

data.title: Integrated Terminal doesn't clean properly when using bash on Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [10.0.14393]
- GNU bash: 4.3.42(5)-release

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Define the shell as bash by using: `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe"`.
2. Open terminal with `CTRL + '` or **View > Integrated Terminal**.
3. Run commands and try to clear with `clear` command or `CTRL + L` shortcut.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7119058/19506231/86c147fe-95a8-11e6-80e9-a95695e389fd.png)

> Actually, this occurs only with bash (no problems with default `cmd.exe` running `cls`).

data.title: Find in Selection in any selection, not just by lines
data.body: In VS Code, Find in Selection only works by lines, if you have a multiline selection. In other editors, I can select any fragment and search within it. If anyone uses this, I think it would be more useful to match this. Especially for minified files with very large lines. And after https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/79bc7a814603d541502a604e0f984aee7abba90f, it makes more sense. Since before, if you accidentally selected two characters, you'd be stuck searching in there.

data.title: Cannot open Visual Studio Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code

When I launch it, the app icon appears in the dock and it closes when I click it.
Tried with `code --disable-extensions` and the same.

If I type `code --list-extensions` on console it logs the following:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4268555/19499720/57ee27ec-956e-11e6-93c9-f7cf6207b341.png)

I have tried removing app data, uninstalling and installing again, deleting cache, and always the same result.

VSCode Insiders works well.

data.title: Option to only have a single instance running
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

I really like VS Code, but the only thing preventing me from doing a full switch from Textpad as my multi-purpose and fast text editor is being able to have all file opens use the same VS Code window with tabs.  In Textpad, it’s not default, but it has:

![vscode_tpref](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6612225/19499306/91c19e5a-954a-11e6-8257-68421bd52a4c.png)

When unselected, ensures that any file opened via double click or via the right click file menu:

![vscode_tcontext](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6612225/19499328/b7376bec-954a-11e6-8d22-87fde733a948.png)

Opens in my same instance of Textpad.  I find it much easier to navigate the document selector or tabs than multiple instances of Textpad through windows:

![vscode_tdocs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6612225/19499340/d1d625a6-954a-11e6-9884-06d3d6815575.png)

Is just easier to see and switch back and forth than:

![vscode_twin](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6612225/19499351/df031374-954a-11e6-8307-020d0bd37924.png) 

Thanks for an awesome editor!

data.title: Support Per-Workspace Environment Variable Settings and Path Specifications
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1 (1.6.1)
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.6 (15G1004)

User story: As a developer, I would like VS Code to offer a per-workspace setting that lets me replace (or augment) VS Code's environment variables with my own dictionary of key-value pairs.

User story: As a developer, I would like VS Code to offer the ability to reference pre-existing variables in my definition and apply expansion to them.

``` javascript
{
// Editor

  // Controls the environment variables.
  "editor.environment": {
    "GOPATH": "./pkg",
    "PATH": "${HOME}/bin:./pkg/bin:${PATH}"    
  }
}
```

Before you write this issue off as absurd, consider Mac OS X as a platform.  Propagating environment variables to non-command line applications is especially problematic and breaks between major operating system releases:
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30118993/how-to-set-environment-variables-in-yosemite
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25385934/setting-environment-variables-via-launchd-conf-no-longer-works-in-os-x-yosemite

The motivating discovery behind filing this is the [Go Programming Language](http://www.golang.org)'s reliance on environment variables for controlling its execution environment, package search path, runtime, build tools, etc:
- https://golang.org/doc/code.html#GOPATH
- https://golang.org/cmd/go/

The issue transcends the [popular Go plugin](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go).

data.title: "stick" checkbox on color theme picker
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: 10.11.6

When you open the color theme picker, you can only select one theme before it closes. It would be nice to have a way to keep the picker open so you can try several themes before picking a winner.

data.title: Unwanted angle bracket autocompletion in TypeScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: Windows 10

When writing code in TypeScript, I often go to fix an expression by changing the comparison operator. I'll highlight the operator, such as the `>=` in `if(a >= b) { ...`, then type the correct operator, such as `<`. In VS Code 1.6, I've noticed that it is treating angle brackets in the same way as other types of brackets when applied to a selection, presumably for the purposes of improved editing of casting syntax and generic type arguments. In my example above, this means that rather than replacing my selection with the correct operator, it changes `>=` into `<>=>`, which is obviously not what was desired.

I want autocompletion in general, but I'd like to turn it off for angle brackets in TypeScript, as I find it more of a hindrance than a help. Is there an option for this, and if not, could it be added in a future version of VS Code? Note that turning it off should be a language-specific feature, as it would be undesirable to also turn it off for tsx, jsx, xml and html.

data.title: Hide explorer by default
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607

How do we make explorer not to forcibly show when opening a file? It's wasting space. Can't find anything related with hide explorer, show explorer, hide sidebar, show sidebar with in:title. There is some "explorer.autoReveal" in settings, but setting it to false doesn't seem to do anything.

data.title: VSCode is using a lot of the CPU on this Mac with the CPP extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:27:10.246Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: Kasik96.swift-0.0.2, Orta.vscode-ios-common-files-1.0.2, TimonVS.ReactSnippetsStandard-1.0.3, TwentyChung.jsx-0.0.1, alechp.react-toolbox-snippets-0.12.0, cdsama.shell-snippets-0.1.2, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.8, donjayamanne.githistory-0.1.0, dzannotti.vscode-babel-coloring-0.0.4, eg2.tslint-0.5.39, flowtype.flow-for-vscode-0.3.3, gllwy.theme-dusk-0.0.7, groksrc.ruby-0.0.6, kube.ClangComplete-0.0.4, mitaki28.vscode-clang-0.2.1, ms-vscode.cpptools-0.9.2, ornithologist.ios-snippets-0.0.15, rebornix.Ruby-0.9.0, redhat.java-0.0.5, robertohuertasm.vscode-icons-3.0.5, rtorr.vscode-flow-276.3.0, vsmobile.vscode-react-native-0.2.0, waderyan.babelrc-1.0.0, xabikos.ReactSnippets-1.2.0

It appears to be related to `Microsoft.VSCode.CPP.Extension.darwin` and `parentalcontrolsd`. When I run VSCode the CPU is used heavily and the fan makes a lot of noise. This is happening just recently when I started using VSCode with C code. Specifically I am viewing code for the `pjsim` project on GitHub. Perhaps loading up that project on a Mac (El Capitan) with VSCode will be a way to reproduce the problem.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone `pjsim` project from GitHub https://github.com/chakrit/pjsip
2. Open that folder with VSCode
3. Install the recommended plugins for C/C++
4. Restart VSCode
5. Wait for the CPP plugins to wreak havoc on all that is good and holy

It appears to not cause any trouble without the recommended CPP plugins. The Microsoft CPP and Clang plugins for C/C++ have been downloaded a lot and have high ratings so I expected them to be alright.

One potentially important detail is that I am running a beta release of Xcode (8.1 beta 3) and have that path selected with `Xcode-select`. If that is somehow the cause for this trouble it would be best to resolve it before the final 8.1 release is out.

data.title: Feature Request: Show all errors and warnings in project for all files, not just opened ones

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am using VS Code on a project at work that has hundreds of files and many layers of nested sub-directories. I frequently make changes that break many files, such as changing the call signature of a commonly used method. Since the project is entirely typescript, it is useful to be able to open the "Problems" view and see the errors and warnings my change caused in the files I have open. However, because of the size of the project, I still need to go to my terminal and run our own make commands to see the list of problems. I then need to perform the fun dance between my terminal and VS Code, searching for the right line in the right file before I can fix the problem.

What I need is a way to tell the "Problems"  view to show me all errors and warnings across all open and closed files in my project. This would allow me to see all problems in a single list and quickly click through and fix them.

data.title: auto completion of braces in typescript files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: macOS sierra

Love VSCode but I am missing some intellisense from R#
When I type myClass. I get list of members. when I choose one and tab it would be nice if VSCode could add braces.

Behaviour today: myClass.showNextPage
desired behaviour: myClass.showNextPage();
If there are parameters place the cursor between the braces. else at the end of the line
